TXT_KEY_BUGOPTIONS_SCORES_DISPLAYORDER_HOVER This determines the order in which the score columns appear.
\S - The civ's score.
\C - The civ's/leader's name.
\? - You have not yet met the civ.
\W - You are at war with the civ.
\E - You have a positive espionage point ratio against the civ.
\P - The civ's power ratio compared to you.
\T - The tech the civ is researching (vassals, teammates and espionage).
\U - The number of research turns left.
\N - The civ is connected to your trade network.
\B - You have an open borders agreement with the civ.
\D - You have a defensive pact with the civ.
\R - The civ's state religion.
\A - The civ's attitude toward you.
\* - You are waiting for this civ to finish its turn.
\L - Civ's network stats (ping).
\O - The network player is out-of-sync. This determines the order in which the score columns appear.

TXT_KEY_BUGOPTIONS_UNITNAME_ENABLED_HOVER When checked, uses the formats on this tab and in the INI file to name the player's units. \Names can be built from plain text and format codes that appear between matching carets (^).
\ - e.g. "^cv^ ^ut^ from ^ct^" --> "American Archer from Boston"

\General Codes:
\ - civ4 - Use built-in Civ4 names
\ - rd - Random name
\ - rc - Random civ-related name
\Unit Info Codes:
\ - ct - City where unit was built (e.g. Boston)
\ - cv - Civilization that built the unit in adjective form (e.g. American)
\ - ut - Unit type (e.g. Archer)
\ - cb - Combat type (e.g. Melee)
\ - dm - Domain type (e.g. Water)
\ - ld - Leader that built the unit (e.g. Roosevelt)
\Counting Codes:
\ - cnt[f] - Count across all units
\ - cntu[f] - Count per unit type
\ - cntct[f] - Count per city
\ - cntuct[f] - Count per unit/city combination
\ - cntc[f] - Count per combat type
\ - cntd[f] - Count per domain
\ - tt1[f][x:y] - Count up to a number chosen between x and y
\ - tt1[f][x] - Count from x, incrementing each time tt1 code is reset
\ * f in [f] is one of s, A, a, p, g, n, o, r (see help file) When checked, uses the formats on this tab and in the INI file to name the player's units. \Names can be built from plain text and format codes that appear between matching carets (^).
